contextId.information: Here "lusts of their hearts" is a synecdoche that represents the evil things they wanted to do. AT: "the morally impure things they desired greatly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: the lusts of their hearts for uncleanness

contextId.information: This is a synecdoche for the whole body. AT: "body" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Here "letter" is a synecdoche that refers to written Scripture. AT: "through the work of the Holy Spirit, not because you know the Scriptures" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: in the Spirit, not in the letter

contextId.information: Here "feet" is a synecdoche that represents the people themselves. The word "blood" is a metaphor that refers to killing people. AT: "They are in a hurry to harm and murder people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: Their feet are swift to pour out blood

contextId.information: Here "fear" is a metonym that represents respect for God and willingness to honor him. AT: "Everyone refuses to give God the respect he deserves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: There is no fear of God before their eyes

contextId.information: Here "mouth" is a synecdoche that means the words people speak. You can translate this in an active form. AT: "so that no people will be able to say anything valid to defend themselves" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: in order that every mouth may be shut

contextId.information: The picture is of the sinner offering the "parts of his body" to his master or king. One's "body parts" are a synecdoche for the whole person. AT: "Do not offer yourselves to sin so that you do what is not right" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Do not present the parts of your body to sin, to be tools used for unrighteousness

contextId.information: Here "parts of your body" is a synecdoche that refers to the whole person. AT: "let God use you for what is pleasing to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: present the parts of your body to God as tools to be used for righteousness

contextId.information: Here "body parts" refers to the whole person. AT: "offer yourselves as slaves to what is right before God so that he might set you apart and give you the power to serve him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: present your body parts as slaves to righteousness for sanctification

contextId.information: The word "mouth" is a synecdoche that refers to what a person says. AT: "it is in what you say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

Here Paul uses the word "bodies" to refer to the whole person. Paul is comparing a believer in Christ who completely obeys God to the animals that the Jews killed and then offered to God. AT: "to offer yourselves completely to God while you are alive as if you were a dead sacrifice on a temple altar" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
contextId.quote: to present your bodies a living sacrifice

contextId.information: Here "soul" is a synecdoche for the whole person. "Every Christian should obey" or "Everyone should obey" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: Let every soul be obedient to

contextId.information: Here the words "Macedonia" and "Achaia" are synecdoches for the people who live in those areas. AT: "the believers in the provinces of Macedonia and Achaia were happy" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
contextId.quote: it was the good pleasure of Macedonia and Achaia
